title: Question 136

children: A 58-year-old man undergoes a wellness examination. Medical and family histories are unremarkable. He has never smoked cigarettes, does not drink alcohol, and takes no medications. Screening colonoscopy for colorectal cancer was performed 8 years ago and was negative. Depression screening is negative. Immunizations are up to date. He has never had screening for prostate cancer.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in prostate cancer screening for this patient?

text.__html: Digital rectal examination and prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing
Measurement of PSA velocity over time
One-time PSA testing at age 60 years
Discussion of prostate cancer screening risks and benefits

children: All major professional organizations encourage patients to discuss the potential harms and benefits of prostate cancer screening with their physician before making individual decisions.
Guidelines recommend not screening for prostate cancer in men who do not express a preference.
The most appropriate next step is to discuss the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening (

) with this patient. Guidance on screening for prostate cancer among men at average risk is controversial and continues to evolve. Early diagnosis has not been shown to reduce morbidity or mortality due to prostate cancer. Screening carries risks related to prostate specific antigen (PSA) testing as well as harms from subsequent diagnosis and treatment. PSA testing frequently produces false-positive results, as PSA elevation is seen not only in prostate cancer but also in prostatitis and benign prostatic hyperplasia. This can lead to anxiety and unnecessary prostate biopsies. The harms of biopsies include pain, infection, urinary obstruction, and hematospermia. Screening for prostate cancer also leads to overdiagnosis (the diagnosis of cancer that would not become clinically apparent or caused harm in the patient's lifetime), and treatment of these patients exposes them to potential long-term harms, including urinary incontinence, erectile dysfunction, and bowel dysfunction. Thus, all major professional organizations encourage patients to discuss the potential harms and benefits of prostate cancer screening with their physician before making individual decisions. It is reasonable to initiate these conversations at age 50 years with average-risk patients with a life expectancy of at least 10 years.
The patient should not undergo digital rectal examination (

) for prostate cancer screening due to its poor sensitivity and specificity for prostate cancer. In addition, the physician should discuss the risks and benefits of prostate cancer screening before measuring the PSA (
). The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommends not screening for prostate cancer in patients who do not express a preference.
Methods for better use of PSA testing, such as PSA velocity (
) and doubling time, one-time PSA measurement at prespecified ages (
), and adjusted-threshold testing, are being investigated. However, there is currently insufficient evidence to support these methods.

objective.__html: Discuss risk and benefits of prostate cancer screening.

references: Grossman DC, Curry SJ, Owens DK, et al; US Preventive Services Task Force. Screening for prostate cancer: US Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. JAMA. 2018;319:1901-1913.
